Description: Described as a 'Carnelian ring, burnt'. Finger-ring (thumb-ring; archer's ring); carved carnelian; the hoop has a projection on the back. The high projecting bezel terminating in a point (broken) representing a cut stone.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Illustrated in the original Naukratis publication (Petrie 1886, pl. xx.26) and described as a 'carnelian ring, burnt', Petrie compares it to an agate ring in the British Museum (H.58; Dalton 1912, 2342) which is dated to the 15th–16th centuries AD. A similar piece in carnelian (British Museum, AF.2321; Dalton 1912, 2362) is dated to the 17th century BC. Dalton, O. M. 1912, Franks Bequest Catalogue of the Finger Rings, Early Christian, Byzantine, Teutonic, Mediaeval and Later, Bequeathed by Sir Augustus Wollaston Franks, KCB, in which are included the other rings of the same period in the Museum, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (QA.07) (Phase 3)
